actualResults.title: Missing X-Frame-Options Header - Clickjacking Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security misconfiguration finding. The absence of X-Frame-Options header allows the application to be embedded in iframes, enabling clickjacking attacks. This is a new discovery not in the expected findings list.

actualResults.title: Missing X-Content-Type-Options Header - MIME Sniffing Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security misconfiguration finding. The missing X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff header allows browsers to MIME-sniff responses, potentially executing malicious content as scripts. This is a new discovery representing poor security header configuration.

actualResults.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy (CSP) Header
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate defense-in-depth finding. The absence of CSP removes an important browser-level security layer that could mitigate XSS attacks even when input validation fails. This is a new discovery highlighting missing security headers.

actualResults.title: Server Header Information Disclosure - Outdated Technology Stack
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate information disclosure finding. The Server header exposes Werkzeug/1.0.1 and Python/2.7.18 version information, enabling attackers to research specific vulnerabilities. This is a new discovery about verbose server headers.

actualResults.title: Missing Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) Header
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security misconfiguration finding. The absence of HSTS leaves users vulnerable to protocol downgrade attacks and SSL stripping. This is a new discovery about missing transport security headers.

actualResults.title: Application Logic Flaw - Consistent Internal Server Error on Valid Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate availability/reliability finding. The /xss2 endpoint consistently returns HTTP 500 errors due to a missing check_xss() function, making the endpoint non-functional. This is a new discovery about application stability issues.

actualResults.title: Flask Application Missing SECRET_KEY Configuration
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security misconfiguration finding. While currently limited impact since sessions aren't used, the missing SECRET_KEY represents security debt that could lead to vulnerabilities if session management is added. This is a new discovery about Flask configuration weaknesses.

actualResults.title: Outdated Python 2.7 and Werkzeug 1.0.1 With Known Vulnerabilities
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate vulnerable components finding. Python 2.7 reached EOL in January 2020 and has numerous unpatched CVEs (CVE-2021-3177, CVE-2019-9674, CVE-2021-23336). Werkzeug 1.0.1 is also outdated with known security issues. This is a new discovery about using unmaintained, vulnerable software components.

matched.expectedTitle: Cross-Site Scripting via Image Source Attribute
matched.actualTitle: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via Insufficient Input Sanitization in /xss2 Endpoint
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same XSS vulnerability in the /xss2 endpoint. The expected finding describes XSS where URL sanitization can be bypassed to inject malicious content into an image src attribute. The actual finding confirms this exact vulnerability, detailing how the regex filtering is insufficient (lines 67-77), allowing XSS through event handlers (onerror, onload), javascript: URIs, data: URIs, and attribute injection. Both reference the same code location, describe the same attack vectors (malformed image URLs bypassing regex checks), and identify the same impact (arbitrary JavaScript execution, cookie theft, session hijacking). The actual finding provides more detailed analysis with 4/5 POC payloads successfully bypassing filters, confirming the expected vulnerability.
